text: With onset of COVID, one of our financial services customers saw a four times increase in call volumes to their contact center.
Which very quickly overwhelmed their on premise legacy infrastructure.
Our customers were keen to fix this and they partnered with AWS to move their contact center to cloud,
using Amazon Connect, which is our contact center in cloud service.

During the first phase, we work with
our customers to understand their requirements,
both functional and nonfunctional.

These are things like how many agents
they expect to see on their platform,

how many concurrent customers
they expect to come on their platform,

also things like different languages
that they're keen to support and
also various systems their contact center
is supposed to integrate with.
Once we've understood the requirements, we work with customers to help define an architecture that best meets their requirements
and also is as per AWS Well-Architected Framework which provides prescriptive guidance to build on cloud.
We also worked with customers to help them set up the delivery team as they were looking at an expedited timeline for this project.
They partnered with APN Partner Organizations, who are expert in Amazon Connect

and also have years of experience
delivering value for customers in cloud.
This helped them not only bring in expertise for Amazon Connect to their team, but also very quickly
within a matter of weeks enhance their developer capacity that was available to their in-house team.

During the second phase, multidisciplinary team
comprising of product managers,
architects, engineers and QA,

both from customer and AWS partner organization
work side by side using SCRUM methodology
to deliver minimum viable product.
The launch stage is divided into three sub phases.

The first one is pre-launch activities.
These typically comprise of different kinds of testing,

say for example, resilience testing,
performance testing, penetration testing,

which help customers really
understand that the platform
is fit for purpose to go live.

At this stage, also our technical implementation
plan is created, which details step-by-step,

the activities that need to be
performed on the actual go-live day.

On the actual day of go-live, there's an AWS
support team at hand to help customers

navigate if there are any
last minute hiccups or issues.

And once the go-live has happened,
then the actual measures of success are evaluated

to ensure that the platform is supporting
the business as it is meant to be.

These would be metrics like average agent and link time,
number of concurrent calls the platform is supporting.
As the customer's contact center was migrated to cloud, they immediately began to see the value of their investments
as now their contact center was able to scale based on call volumes, and the agent capacity was then no longer dependent on lockdowns in subsequent COVID-19 waves.
With other small and medium businesses, we have worked with them to use Amazon WorkSpaces and AppStream

to build secure desktop solutions,
which have been used by businesses to support
remote working and contract employees.

Customers have also used Amazon Chime SGK
to build real time communication apps,
which are quick to develop and fast to scale.
Providing an enhanced customer support experience is critical to small and medium businesses.

With Amazon Connect contact center offering,
they're able to scale their platform
and pay only when their customers actually use the platform.
This leads to cost savings for their businesses and they're able to support the customers with a very minimal IT team.
